definition: hard-earned money
blood/colloquial pr. [xie3]/CL:滴[di1],片[pian4]
perspiration/sweat/CL:滴[di1],頭|头[tou2],身[shen1]/to be speechless (out of helplessness, embarrassment etc) (Internet slang used as an interjection)
see 可汗[ke4 han2], 汗國|汗国[han2 guo2]
coin/money/CL:筆|笔[bi3]/unit of weight, one tenth of a tael 兩|两[liang3]
surname Qian

sentences.english: Playing computer games all day lavishes parents' hard-earned money.
sentences.chinese: 整天玩電腦遊戲浪費父母的血汗錢。

sentences.english: Forget about throwing billions more of taxpayer money at Motown.
sentences.chinese: 別再打算拿幾十億納稅人血汗錢往汽車城打水漂了。

sentences.english: If you are smart, you will spend your hard-earned money (or your parents') somewhere else.
sentences.chinese: 如果你是聰明的，你會花你的血汗錢在其他地方。

sentences.english: There laws are very stringent and anybody swindles public money will be executed.
sentences.chinese: 法律應該嚴懲那些企圖騙取人民血汗錢的惡人。

sentences.english: So which deserves your hard-earned cash?
sentences.chinese: 那麼，誰更對得起你的血汗錢呢？

sentences.english: Playing computer games squanders parents' hard-earned cash.
sentences.chinese: 打遊戲機浪費父母的血汗錢。

sentences.english: The American People need to know who is costing them their hard earned money.
sentences.chinese: 美國人民需要知道是誰把他們的血汗錢給糟蹋了。

sentences.english: But I dont know whether I can get back my hard-earned money or not.
sentences.chinese: 但我不知道我能否找回我的血汗錢與否。

sentences.english: Fooling around with hard-earned savings is asking for trouble.
sentences.chinese: 有了點血汗錢就遊手好閒，那是自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: How to make good use of money in advertising investment?
sentences.chinese: 楊柳新年，一把廣告血汗錢應該怎麼投？

sentences.english: The money is made from fresh and blood of my parents.
sentences.chinese: 這是父母賺回來的血汗錢。

definition: it's the most capable people who do the most work (idiom) (intended as consolation for the overworked, or flattery when making a request etc)
lit. to return to office after living as a hermit on Mount Dongshan (idiom); fig. to make a comeback
priceless treasure
to spare no effort
to save on food and clothing (idiom); to live frugally
lit. look into one's heart, no shame (idiom); with a clear conscience
high denomination of banknotes or coins/lots of money/a big sum (e.g. a bribe)
proficiency in a particular field (idiom)/skill in a specialized area (idiom)
royalty (on books)
to work hard/to look after
to support one's family (idiom); to have difficulty feeding a family
penniless (idiom)
to be reluctant to give up a post
tip/gratuity/monetary reward/bonus
empty-handed (idiom); fig. not receiving anything
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
